data.title: Haydamaky to perform first U.S. concert at Soyuzivka's Ukrainian ...
data.meta_description: Haydamaky to perform first U.S. concert at Soyuzivka's Ukrainian ...
data.text: INSIDE: • Protest against Russian interference in Ukraine – page 4. • Ukrainian religious treasures in New York – page 11. • Soyuzivka, before it became Soyuzivka – page 15. THE UKRAINIAN WEEKLY Published by the Ukrainian National Association Inc., a fraternal non-profit association Vol. LXXVIII No. 27 THE UKRAINIAN WEEKLY SUNDAY, JULY 4, 2010 $1/$2 in Ukraine Haydamaky to perform first U.S. concert at Soyuzivka’s Ukrainian Cultural Festival Haydamaky Haydamaky, Ukraine’s biggest ethno-rock band, will perform at Soyuzivka on July 17. by Zenon Zawada Kyiv Press Bureau KYIV – Rockers Haydamaky – the headliners at the upcoming 2010 Ukrainian Cultural Festival at Soyuzivka – were among the most fervent supporters of the Orange Revolution, having explored Europe and seen the benefits of Western society. The band describes itself as a Ukrainian musical formation that thinks European. “It all began in the ‘90s, when we weren’t yet Haydamaky,” lead singer Oleksandr Yarmola told The Weekly during a recent interview at a pizza café situated in the outer rings of Kyiv. “We then began to travel to Poland, then Germany, and opened for ourselves the Western world. We played on the streets, weddings, played in clubs, and in punk clubs, where the hardest punk was played.” The band became the Haydamaky, as its website notes, changing its name “in honor of those who fought in Haydamachyna (a peasant rebellion against foreign oppression in 18th-century Ukraine). The new name associated the band’s music with ideas of freedom and justice, establishing an even tighter link with Ukrainian folk culture, and taking the band to a totally new stage.” A decade later, Haydamaky have achieved worldwide admiration, performing their ethno-rock on the main stage of the August 2009 Sziget rock festival in Budapest, central Europe’s largest, and Toronto’s Ukrainian Festival in September 2009. After performing this year in places as diverse as Siberia, Switzerland and Slovakia, Haydamaky will venture into the Catskill region of upstate New York to perform their first U.S. concert at the Soyuzivka Heritage Center on July 17 during the fourth annual Ukrainian Cultural Festival. Given it will be their first time visiting New York City, Mr. Yarmola said the band welcomes any offers to show them around the city that never sleeps. Afterwards, it’s on to Calgary and Edmonton (Alberta), and then to Winnipeg and Canada’s National Ukrainian Festival at Dauphin, (Manitoba). “I had very pleasant impressions,” Mr. Yarmola said of his first trip to Canada last year. “It’s not like Europe at all. Well, perhaps Sweden and Scandinavia a bit. There are lots of forests, wide spaces and skyline there too.” The band’s global acclaim is built upon a decade of experimenting with a multitude of different musical styles, blending reggae, punk and ska rhythms and beats with Ukrainian melodies. Yet Haydamaky have demonstrated they’re perpetually experimenting, with some albums incorporating styles as diverse as rap. Last year, Haydamaky produced an album with the Polish jazz-rock heroes Voo Voo. Its flexibility is made possible by the band’s seven-member format, including drummer Sergij Borysenko, guitarist Oleksandr Demyanenko, bass Volodymyr Sherstyuk, trumpet player Sergij Solovij (Continued on page 13) The first 100 days: Yanukovych aims for total control of civil activity by Zenon Zawada Kyiv Press Bureau The first 100 days: The Ukrainian Weekly examines the activity of the administration of President Viktor Yanukovych in Ukraine’s cultural life, economy, and foreign and domestic policy. This is the fourth article in the series. KYIV – It was the former German Ambassador to Ukraine Ditmar Studemann who first publicly acknowledged that authoritarianism had returned to Ukrainian government. “The domestic policy of Ukraine after the first 100 days of the new government can be characterized as concentrated on stabilization at least, but authoritarian all the same,” Mr. Studemann told the Deutsche Welle news agency in an interview published June 4. His cause for alarm was justified when three weeks later his fellow countryman, Niko Lange, the Kyiv director of the Konrad Adenauer Fund, was held at Kyiv Boryspil airport for 10 hours after criticizing the administration of Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych. Both Germans warned the Yanukovych administration that Euro-integration wouldn’t be possible for Ukraine if its government pursued authoritarian policies such as repressing and persecuting the opposition, abusing the law for political ends and imposing police state measures on a peaceful population. Ironically, the Yanukovych administration reacted with the same neo-Soviet tactics of intimidation against Mr. Lange that he warned against. As a result, any pretense that the Yanukovych administration wants to build a democratic, European Ukraine where the rule of law is paramount has evaporated. “Not understanding civilized conduct, the people in government will act very aggressively, like in African or Asian dictatorships,” said Dr. Oleh Soskin, the director of (Continued on page 22) Volodymyr Hontar/UNIAN The Yanukovych administration keeps protesters under control, as in this June 10 demonstration in Kyiv held under the slogan “No to a police state.” Is Kyiv’s foreign policy balanced by Zenon Zawada Kyiv Press Bureau Below is a continuation of last week’s article in “The first 100 days” series focusing on the foreign policy of the Yanukovych administration. KYIV – Upon taking office in February, the Yanukovych administration went to great lengths to create an image as a balancer between Russian and European interests in Ukraine. As a symbolic step, President Viktor Yanukovych’s first foreign visit was to Brussels. In April, a month after becoming prime minister, Mykola Azarov told Swedish Foreign Minister Carl Bildt that he set for his government the goals of achieving a European Union Association Agreement and a free-trade agreement by the year’s end. In June, he said Ukrainians would have visa-free travel to Europe as early as 2011. An EU integration action for 2010 was even drafted. Yet, veteran observers of the Ukrainian political scene are calling it all a bluff. Actions and trends reveal the (Continued on page 16)
